job_title: Patient Care Technician in Seattle, WA
pros: Jones pavilion is a very nice facility, quality healthcare, okay pay and benefits, seems to be well organized and well staffed more often than not.
cons: I was an employee here for 3+ years and got along with everyone. I followed the rules, I was great with my patients, I left with plenty of positive references and friends. I liked the company so much, I decided to return (I was told to call anytime). Upon getting ahold of my former manager, I learned I was flagged as ineligible for rehire. Rumor has it that I had spoken negatively about another employee, something I was never confronted with or given a chance to defend. The conversation was brutal to say the least, my inquiries were met with enthusiastic and cheerful professionalism despite the nature of the discussion. I construed this cheerful tone delivering bad news with no intent to listen to anything I had to say as joy. This was very hard to swallow, for 3 years I was in high standing with everyone I worked with, many of the staff I've stayed in contact with have offered to write letters of recommendation to HR about my return. In the short 3 months I worked under my interim manager, a very negative opinion was developed and my reputation with VM was gone. I later received a very direct and not so polite email demanding that I stop calling the facility, despite my invitation to call and inquire anytime. I've attempted to file a grievance with HR, but I have yet to hear back. I feel humiliated, slandered, vilified and unjustly cast out. This is not what I expected from a hospital like Virginia Mason.

pros: VMMC is unique in its ability to marry the rigorous, data-driven commitment to quality and self-improvement of an academic hospital with the outstanding patient experience of a private hospital. A culture of "yes we can" permeates every level of the center, and employees do not hesitate to help patients and colleagues when a need is seen.
cons: By focusing its resources on people, data, and processes, VMMC has not been able to beautify its physical plant. Consequently, some of the older wings are an eyesore. Also, because its reputation has outgrown its physical size, VMMC sees unusually high patient volumes for an isolated health care system, which can spread staff thin and sometimes result in long wait times for some departments. Finally, years ago VMMC selected Cerner as its electronic medical record software, which is now losing market share to Epic and becoming an inferior platform. As most of modern health care is ultimately about managing information and communication, VMMC is increasingly obliged to compensate for weaknesses inherent in Cerner.

job_title: Applications Engineer, Senior in Seattle, WA
pros:
Upbeat and skilled staff in IS Dept. In 19 years as a full-time employee (now retired, working part-time), I had very few conflicts with fellow workers, and was fortunate to work with and for some remarkable individuals. A culturally diverse employee population with many women and minorities in key positions.
I was always provided with the hardware and resources needed to do my job and improve on its service level to others in the organization. IS management keen to keep its focus on serving the needs of employees throughout the organization, and ultimately, to the improvement of the patient experience. Compensation was above average. Raises and promotions came when deserved. I would unhesitatingly recommend IS at Virginia Mason as a good place to work.
cons: One major misstep was made, in my opinion, at a high level in deciding to implement a software product without seeking feedback on it from the future implementation team.

review_title: Cognitive Dissonance between research and employee treatment
pros: The salary was competitive and the health benefits were great.
cons:
Despite doing research as to the importance of word-life balance and parental leave, policies for VM employees are horrible. The vacation benefits are very slim, and even though you *can* take up to 12 weeks of maternity/parental leave, you can only be paid for up to 6 of it, regardless of how much vacation or sick time you have accrued. Don't start here if you are planning on having kids any time soon.  |
Management was also unreasonably strict about punctuality. There was very little empathy for being even 5-10 minutes late at the start of a shift, even for non-clinical staff. Being 7 minutes late twice in a six month period could lead to an HR write up. This policy can be tough to navigate in a city with traffic as bad as Seattle's. This may be less of an issue for people in the satellite clinics.

pros: Certified, professional, medical, assistant, wages
cons: Offers, offers, offers, offers, offers

review_title: Not free thinkers but appreciative of being patient oriented.
pros: Compensation is higher than the average. Fair pay DOE between male and female employees. Everyone is focused on helping the patient or anyone who looks lost, they will walk you to your appointment or meeting and that is expected to be done and you will be recognized for doing this.
cons: There is a standard practice that does not leave any room for creativity on even the lowest level. Mid-level management cannot make a decision on their own, they need approval from upper management to do anything. Also there is a clique mentality and nepotism when it comes to supervisors and the support staff. If you become friends with the supervisors you can do no wrong.

pros:
Competitive wages and benefits for the area. 75% transit subsidy is greatly appreciated and kind of makes up for the fact that employees aren't allowed to park on campus. 

The "lean" culture is unique, and encourages ideas for improvement from staff at any level.
cons:
Patient "satisfaction" seems to trump patient safety and responsible use of resources. Sometimes I don't know if I work in a hospital or a hotel. There seems to be a general fear of repercussion for setting proper boundaries with patients and their families. 

I echo prior sentiments regarding inadequate training for patient care staff to safely work with our growing psychiatric population. When you fear for your own safety at work, it's easy to fall victim to compassion fatigue.

Technology isn't utilized as well as it could be. VM could stand to take some cues from other hospitals.

review_title: Pass on the Kool Aid but negotiate a good salary
pros: The rank and file work hard and really care about the patients.  Everyone is helpful and respectful toward co-workers as well.  The philosophy sounds great and LEAN principles make sense on paper.  Because salaries are good, many employees put up with working conditions.
cons: VMMC has gone too far in it's attempt to cut costs.  Many behind the scenes employees work in squalor and are treated like slaves.  They are encouraged to skip lunch and breaks and are in constant fear of being fired. As a new employee, iIt only takes a few days to realize that you will be asked to commit hari kari if you make an honest mistake.  That is the Japanese (LEAN) way.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Seattle, WA
pros: So as the saying goes " the grass isn't always greener on the other side of the fence." I didn't appreciate what VM had until I left the state for a large, world renowned university hospital. I wish I had never left! Is VMPS tedious at times? Of course, but it also gets results. I am amazed at how well VMMC has incorporated the production system into every facet of the business while still giving superior care. I never had any complaints as a patient or employee. And to be honest, didn't realize how much I had learned until I started my new job and everyone looked at me like I was crazy when I mentioned having Standard Work.
cons:
Parking, as some have said is heinous downtown but you can get reimbursed for most of it. 
If you're not prepared or willing to embrace constant change, then don't bother applying. Innovation is key at VMMC.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: I love the organization and I think they really have values that line up with improving and changing the organization to be better. They also stay small and focus on doing things better not bigger and then growing smaller over time. This helps them be strong with their budget and spending on things that are really needed.
cons: Bureaucracy still plagues the ability to get things done. The budget consciousness often leads to inefficiencies because money is not spent. I don't think my floor gets cleaned properly and a lot of non-MA tasks fall to us. Our scope of practice in my department is limited and does not challenge me. Nurses are given clinical work before we are even considered within our scope. Management is based off time in the organization not skill sets and leadership ability and that severely debilitates the ability to implement better working processes.

pros: At Virginia Mason the staff are always friendly and upbeat and I am fortunate to work with some very remarkable individuals. The culture is about valuing diversity, inclusivity and respect for people. The mission and values of the organization are visible  and  the organization's focus on quality, safety and transparency are very apparent in daily work. Virginia Mason provides the resources need to not only do my job but to excel at it. They are focused on serving the needs of the  employees throughout the organization which ultimately drives the improvement of the patient experience. I would not hesitate to recommend Virginia Mason as THE place to work.
cons: The commute into Seattle can at times be a bit long, but overall it is not bad given some of other places I've lived.

pros: VMMC used to be a "family" of experienced support staff. It  was a great place to work and advance. Learning was encouraged and hard work was compensated.
cons: Now youth is key. Low experience, low pay,  big smiles. If one is over 55, highly experienced,  and has worked hard to attain a top salary range WATCH YOURSELF! I have seen six of my esteemed coworkers heads roll,  only to be replaced by cheaper help. Look for grey hair at VM,  you wont find any. Its a very sad change in what VM values,  and the Patient's are the ultimate losers.

review_title: 3years of oncology nursing has brought me opportunities for learning and advancement.

review_title: Great experience & wonderful corporate values. Proud to work here
pros: VM is a wonderful place to work. I've worked for a few companies at this point in my life, and I've never been so proud of the place that I work. The people are wonderful, the corporate leadership actually communicates with every employee (Which I've found to be rare)

Although management does make it a point to compliment you when you put in the hard work, the opportunities for advancement without a specific degree in the healthcare field.

review_title: Brutal elimination of entire department on 1/15/2015
pros: "No layoff" policy...what a lie.  The doctors are good. The management needs a class called "walk a mile in my shoes."  Compassion and loyalty or rewarding employees instead of eliminating their jobs...these values are in short supply.
cons: Reputation of this company must suffer after they callously laid off the entire medical transcription department, eliminating around 60 jobs overall, jobs that were here in this community, paid decent living wages.  All gone.The transcription department, numberi around 20, consisted of older, long term employees (20 years or more), some were blind, and all were shocked that their skills, loyalty and contribution to success  of VM and patient care and safety were valued and respected so little.  An absolute betrayal.  Don't trust them, don't work for them.  You mean nothing.

pros: Great, competitive pay. That's it.
cons: They don't care about their employees well being and health. They will do anything to improve the VM "production system" even if it means making others suffer. The way in which they train their employees is terrible. They had someone that had only worked there 7 months at the time train me. It was scattered and not everyone was on the same page. On top of that, management is incompetent and they're not all on the same page as well. Also, most of the employees are idiots and I don't understand how they even became medical professionals. Don't work there, you will lose your soul.

review_title: Less than qualified manager and HR doesn't care if you have a disability

Don't dare say anything to the HR department you will not have your job almost immediately after contacting them.  They boast as a teaching hospital, which is a direct lie. review_title: VMMC cares more about the process than about the patient.

pros: The people I worked alongside.
cons: Too many PI projects without true meaning.  Too much busy work associated with PI to prove results rather than measuring true results that made a difference.  Management was so far into process improvement that they forgot the people that were truly there for the patients.  That also put the patient at the bottom of the pyramid instead of at the top where they were supposed to be.

review_title: Rewarding place to work when employees are listened to
pros: VM is strongly committed to ensuring save and effective patient care. This leads to the entire care team working together to make that happen. There is almost an equally strong effort to train all employees in Lean Thinking.
cons: Executive leadership is a good ol' boy/girl network, so it's no wonder how some keep their jobs when they shouldn't. Many good employees, including docs, were lost  with the emphasis on Lean Thinking.

job_title: Diagnostic Medical Sonographer in Seattle, WA
pros: Emphasis on teamwork, patient safety, communication transparency, recognition for hard work.  Our CEO Dr Kaplan is a significant figure in health care reform, and we are proud to have him at the helm of VM.
cons: Really depends on who your manager / coworkers are. Most managers / co workers are fantastic but there are always a few sour apples. Had an abusive manger a few years ago in which 12 people from our team resigned and yet upper management did nothing. That was frustrating. The abusive manager has left for a different facility much to our relief, and we hope the next manager will be a better one.

review_title: Losing focus on employee satisfaction with work-life balance, but excellent pay and top-quality patient care.
pros:
VM is truly committed to their patients and puts them first above all else. 
Pay scale is one of the highest in the nation for radiology (90th percentile)
Fast paced, incredible work opportunity to learn and develop skills and experience
Excellent to a fault for managing finances and keeping the hospital up and running. Employees get a bonus if the company does well for the year. 
Fantastic radiologists, surgeons, and PCPs
cons:
The happiness of the employee is at the bottom of the pyramid. In radiology, they are moving toward a model where employees are required to flex their daily schedule anywhere from starting the day at 7am to working till the late hours of the night. They also have to rotate out to all of the satellites which geographically range from Federal Way to Bainbridge island to Lynnwood to Bellevue to Issaquah (although at least the satellite clinics are not open for service all evening). 
Part-time employees are being thinned out as well as people with seniority. Since being  required to flex, a part-time employee will never get a set day to work. It is anywhere from Sunday-Saturday. The management recognizes this and the solution is to turn the part-time positions into full-time positions, thereby eliminating part-time opportunities.
Our group used to be supportive of each other and help each other out if someone couldn't work a certain shift to travel to a certain satellite, but the morale is steeply dropping. In the last 3 years, the turn-over rate has been 9 people and more people will be leaving because of the lack of consideration of the happiness of the employee. "If you don't like it, too bad, you can always leave." Is the motto nowadays. So the department is now full of newbies, on the lower pay scale. Very convenient for the financial bottom line and ridding people who have lost the fight for a work-life balance. 
Vacation time is extremely difficult to get approved and will be until they get a handle on employee satisfaction and are able to retain talented people.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Seattle, WA
pros: I was accepted from the very first interview.  I worked in a department where I had very little patient contact.  I loved the work and the people I worked with.  The job was a perfect fit for my experience and skills.  The atmosphere fostered development, learning and positive changes.  I was a part of the team and was included in decision-making because my position was key in the work.
cons: Virginia Mason is like Group Health, a very individual culture.  Benefits are very low in the vacation accrual for new hires, not negotiable for hourly employees.  Many parts of the work are out-sources.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Seattle, WA
pros: Team work is there and everyone is nice and respectful.  Lots of ancillary support like lab, transport, great techs. Competitive pay. Focus on patient safety.
cons: The health insurance is horrible. If you are planning on having a baby during your time here, find somewhere else to work. Not very good OT or DT policies, short staffed frequently, no float differential. I had 5 patients every day all day. They allow bad managers to stay and move them around instead of getting rid of them. If you want to use your nurses as float pool you need to pay differentials.

review_title: Best medical center in Seattle in every way
pros: High quality, patient-focused care. Great fellow employees. Best doctors anywhere. If you are looking to attach yourself to an organization that cares about its patients, its people and its place in the community, I can't think of a better health care institution than Virginia Mason.
cons: Parking, due to downtown location, can be a challenge to those of us who work day shifts.

pros: They provide generous health benefits. They help reliable employees find new jobs within the company if their job is replaced or the employee needs a change. They have many employees that have been there a long time and are experienced.
cons: There are no performance based raises your salary is based on what they deem to be the 'market value' for your job and your manager has virtually no input. You have to pay for parking, and cannot use the on campus lots during the day.

pros: Very thorough interview process. They check all past employers, education, credit and WSP. I think it's great as you end up with co-workers who are there for a career as well. Hardly any turn over or open jobs. Their benefit package is very competitive. Different tiers of healthcare options as well as Alfac and Willamet Dental.
cons: Hard to get in. After formal interview you are usually hired. My hiring process took from first contact to start date was about three weeks.

review_title: Good company to work for but management's people skills are lacking
pros: Compensation and benefits are some of the best in the industry.  The work environment is very positive.
cons: Unfortunately some of the managers at Virginia Mason have very poor people skills, so employees do not always maximize their potential. As with a lot of large medical centers these days, you are thought of as more of a commodity/number than a person.

review_title: This is the best hospital for nurses
pros:
Progressive = LEAN technologies, means less waste of resources and time, process improvements are encouraged and rewarded
Service-centered = Every single employee is trained and retrained on customer service for patients and coworkers
Safe = Safety is assessed and reassessed with a Stop-the-line access for any employee or patient
Invested = They value and reward their staff and encourage education and career advancement
cons:
Part of the hospital is in an older building
Processes change frequently as they try new ways of doing things

pros: Great patient care. Great respect for people and their ideas. Embraces concept of lean thinking and puts it into production.  My team and I can put our ideas into practice without beuracratic red tape. Wonderful place to work at every day. Some of the best leadership I've ever worked under.
cons: Infrastructure a bit dated, but most hospitals face this. Some staff have been around too long and have a sense of entitlement. Need a better performance management system.

pros:
Great place to work in regard to the people and respect shown to "all".
People are asked to provide good supportive team work and it shows.
Their Lean process provides the ability to give suggestions for improvements.
cons:
Did not provide enough feed back in regard to performance or lack of performance.
Several job duty modifications have resulted in employees taking pay cuts to keep their jobs.

pros: Good compensation - salary, benefits, but for me, that was where it ended.  Even good compensation cannot make up for extremely poor supervisor behavior and a revolving door office.

No parking.  
Laboratory - Histology personnel wear their lab coats outside of the Histology laboratory, into the Pathology office, which is a clean area.  When brought to the attention of "Safety Officer", direct supervisor, Pathology office manager, and finally Lab Director - NOTHING was done.  This goes against OSHA standards for Culture of Safety; lab coats should not be worn outside of Histology lab.  Supervisor micromanages to the extent of holding work up and/or causing double work, calls other employees derogatory names (a very heavyset man in the department was referred to as "Eyore" behind his back - BY THE SUPERVISOR!), and seeks out "help" to pile things up on her choice "target(s)" - Path office is a revolving door, even the typists went home to work, as the office is too hostile.

pros:
Competitive pay, great sick time policy. Vacation accrual increases each year.

pros: Virginia Mason has an interesting patient population. If you're self-sufficient and into learning on your own, then you can learn a lot. They do like to bring in the latest technology and equipment. The pay seems to be better than most places.
cons:
-the pay is high for a reason. If you’re okay with a really high stress, high work volume environment with no support or understanding from your managers….go for it. 

-aside from rare webinars, you will not be provided with opportunities for further learning while on the job. If you want to learn more about what you're actually doing, you'll have to do it on your own. You will never get to attend any conferences unless you request PTO and pay for it yourself.

-technology is brought it in, but then employees must validate it (with no help from the director who purchased it) while still managing patient work-load. So, sometimes you get really cool new stuff and then it sits there collecting dust until someone has the time; or it will be poorly and inefficiently implemented and we’ll all find out 2 years later that we were doing it wrong.

-management is SEVERELY detached from staff. The disconnect is mind-boggling. They do not understand the work you do at all. They have no clue what your actual job is in the lab. 

-the Virginia Mason Production System is a completely warped version of the Toyota Lean/Six Sigma production system. Virginia Mason took a program that should be efficient and turned it on its head. The most poorly executed system I have ever seen in my life. Creates "fake work" for an entire office filled with people to do who knows what, and runs the rest of us in incomprehensible circles. It says right on the VM website that VMPS is supposed to “reduce the burden of work for team members.” HA!! A former VM manager says it best "VM is burying itself in its own rhetoric". We all actually call it “VMBS”…..I think you can figure out what the “BS” stands for.

-the HR business partners at VM *don't even work for VM*. They're contracted through an outside company. So when your team has met with HR for the 3rd time, all of you in tears begging for help, they just don't care. Because they don't even work for the same company. I'm sure some generic response by one of those HR business partners will go below this review and my response to them is -> we begged for your help for 3 years with tears in our eyes and you did literally nothing. Oh wait, you did finally put the supervisor in place that we all actually wanted (again...begged for), but by that time it was a "too little too late" situation and most of the good people left. 

So, then my response to VM hr is do better and do it faster. This is our lives. We don't have years to sit around waiting for the toxic environment (I mean bad managers) to evaporate.

pros: There are some good doctors there and I enjoyed learning from them.
cons: This is literally the worst place to work for. They treat their employees like garbage. I probably took five lunch breaks over the course of nine years because they do absolutely nothing to find you coverage.  When I complained about not getting breaks and lunches, management told me that the time that I spend waiting for a fax to come in while standing at the machine counted as a break. Interesting. I tried for years to make positive changes in my department, but management would not even listen to me. I worked my butt off  for nine years and eventually the company starved me out by reducing my hours to practically nothing. I wasn’t the only one they did this too. This was during the time that they were doing all of the layoffs, but they couldn’t lay me off so those of us who they couldn’t lay off, they starved us out until we quit. Great way to get out of unemployment payments. Coincidentally all of the people who they did this to were the highest paid employees with the most experience. We were replaced by kids right out of school, with no children and who they could pay a lot less.
